required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Inappropriate Sexual Behaviour of Patients Towards French General Practitioners
clinical_study.official_title: Inappropriate Sexual Behaviour (ISB) of Patients Towards French General Practitioners: Prevalence, Nature and Impact on Professional Practice

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de la Réunion

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de la Réunion

brief_summary.textblock: Occupational sexual harassment (HS) has come to the fore in recent years, particularly with the #MeToo social movement that has encouraged women victims of sexual violence to speak out around the world. The medical profession is not exempt from this phenomenon, whether during the training or professional life of practitioners. In France, very little data is available on this subject, particularly among general practitioners. However, the specific nature of the doctor-patient relationship in general practice makes it a potentially high-risk setting. Furthermore, practitioners' experiences of inappropriate sexual behaviour (ISB) can lead to changes in professional practice, and can thus directly influence the quality of care provided to patients. It is also described in the literature that sexual harassment in physicians is independently associated with a decrease in job satisfaction and sense of security at work, and may be associated with an altered mental health status. To date, the only French studies on ISB and HS in medicine have focused on the period of medical study, and none have looked at the particular problem of the patient as perpetrator of the violence. It is in this context that it has been decided to set up this cross-sectional study with the aim of evaluating the prevalence of ISB occurring during consultations with French general practitioners, to describe their characteristics and to evaluate the responses provided and the repercussions on professional practice.

primary_outcome.measure: Prevalence and nature of inappropriate sexual behaviour of patients towards general practitioners in private practice in France
primary_outcome.description: Determined by auto-administered questionnaire (sociodemographic data, personal experience, author's characteristics, reactions and answers provided by the practitioners)

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevalence and nature of Inappropriate sexual behavior between men and women
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the prevalence and nature of Inappropriate sexual behavior according to the gender of the responding physicians

other_outcome.measure: Risk factors associated with sexual inapropriate behavior
other_outcome.description: Identify the risk factors associated determined by auto-administered questionnaire (author's characteristics provided by the practitioners)

other_outcome.measure: Responses of general practitioners to such a situation
other_outcome.description: Describe the responses of general practitioners to such a situation determined by auto-administered questionnaire (answers provided by the practitioners)

other_outcome.measure: Impact and changes on professional practice and personal life.
other_outcome.description: Describe the impact and changes on professional practice and personal life determined by auto-administered questionnaire (reactions provided by the practitioners)

study_pop.textblock: General practitioners in private practice in France.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any general practitioner
- Male or female
- Sole or mixed private practice
- Installed or substitute
- Having completed their internship in general medicine
- With or without a thesis
- Practising alone, in a group practice or in a health centre -
Exclusion Criteria:
- Specialty other than general medicine
- Exclusive hospital or salaried activity
- Refusal to participate
